item.title: Linux kernel module development in Arch Linux based VM
item.description: Linux kernel module (LKM) development is usually conducted inside a VM to prevent corruption of the dev box. Most of the LKM dev. setup guides are targeting Ubuntu based machine, but I love Arch Linux, and there have sparse resources regarding LKM dev. on Arch Linux based VM. So I would like to make a post discussing this. Specifically, I’ll discuss how to make the kernel header that is required for out-of-date (no longer present in Pacman latest database) kernel images.

item.title: So you want to use legacy Linux GPIO?
item.description:
Starting kernel 4.8, a new GPIO interface, GPIO character device, replaced the legacy GPIO interface. The cons of the legacy interface are:

  • State not tied to process
  • Concurrent access to sysfs attributes
  • If process crashes, the GPIOs remain exported
  • Cumbersome API
  • Single sequence of GPIO numbers representing a two-level hierarchy - necessary to calculate the number of the GPIO, numbers not stable

For details, see the maintainer’s slides.

However, there is still plenty of old kernel users relying on the legacy GPIO.
